chapter.summary: Covers the management of suspected sprains and strains in primary care, and prevention of re-injury.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 5 years onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage a suspected sprain or strain in primary care?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
If a person presents with a suspected sprain or strain following initial assessment:

  • Arrange referral to an emergency department if any of the following are present or suspected:
    • A fracture or dislocation. See the section on X-ray clinical decision rules for more information.
    • Damage to nerves or circulation.
    • Wound penetrating the joint or known bleeding disorder.
    • A serious complication such as haemarthrosis or septic arthritis.
    • Tendon rupture.
    • A complete tear, or tear of more than half the muscle belly.
    • A large intramuscular haematoma.
  • Advise on the use of analgesia for symptom relief including cautions and contraindications. 
    • Paracetamol or a topical nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) such as ibuprofen gel is recommended first-line.
    • An oral NSAID such as ibuprofen may be used, if needed.
    • The short-term use of codeine as an 'add on' medication, may be considered.
    • See the CKS topics on Analgesia - mild-to-moderate pain and NSAIDs - prescribing issues for detailed information on prescribing paracetamol, ibuprofen, and codeine.
  • Advise on initial 'PRICE' self-management strategies for the first 48–72 hours after injury.
    • Protection — protect from further injury (for example by using a support or high-top, lace-up shoes).
    • Rest — avoid activity for the first 48–72 hours following injury.
    • Ice — apply ice wrapped in a damp towel for 15–20 minutes every 2–3 hours during the day for the first 48–72 hours following the injury. This should not be left on whilst the person is asleep.
    • Compression — with a simple elastic bandage or elasticated tubular bandage, which should be snug but not tight, to help control swelling and support the injury. This should be removed before going to sleep.
    • Elevation — keep the injured area elevated and supported on a pillow until the swelling is controlled. If the leg is injured, prolonged periods with the leg not elevated should be avoided. For severe sprains and strains, a short period of immobilization for a few days after injury may be needed.
  • Advise on safe return to usual activities and sports, and sources of information and support.
    • Start active mobilization and flexibility (range of motion) exercises as soon as tolerated without excessive pain.
    • Athletes may return to play when there is full, painless range of movement and muscle strength is restored.
    • The NHS patient leaflet Sprains and strains may be helpful.
    • The patient.info leaflets Sprains and strains, Sports injuries, and Ankle injury may be helpful.
  • Consider arranging medical review after 5–7 days, depending on clinical judgement, if there is:
    • Lack of expected improvement (for example they have difficulty walking or weight-bearing).
    • Worsening symptoms (such as increased pain or swelling).
    • Note: consider an alternative diagnosis if symptoms are not improving as expected.
  • Consider arranging a routine referral to physiotherapy if:
    • The person has ongoing symptoms that are not improving as expected despite self-management strategies.
  • Consider arranging referral to orthopaedics, the urgency depending on clinical judgement, if: 
    • Recovery is slower than expected.
    • There are worsening or new symptoms.
    • Symptoms are out of proportion to the mechanism of injury or degree of trauma.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on management are largely based on the International Ankle Consortium publications Consensus statement on the prevalence, impact and long-term consequences of lateral ankle sprains [Gribble, 2016] and Clinical assessment of acute lateral ankle sprain injuries (ROAST): 2019 consensus statement and recommendations [Delahunt, 2018], an overview of systematic reviews on the treatment and prevention of acute and recurrent ankle sprain [Doherty, 2017], a Dutch consensus statement on the diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of ankle sprains [Vuurberg, 2018], US clinical practice guidelines Knee stability and movement coordination impairments: knee ligament sprain [Logerstedt, 2017], two Cochrane systematic reviews Oral non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs versus other oral analgesic agents for acute soft tissue injury [Jones, 2015] and Topical NSAIDs for acute musculoskeletal pain in adults [Derry, 2015], a meta-analysis of studies of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) for acute ankle sprain [van den Bekeron, 2015], a systematic review of the evidence for assessing fracture risk following ankle sprains [Jonckheer, 2015], a systematic review of the management of ankle sprains [Seah, 2011], a systematic review of the effectiveness of conservative management of ankle sprains [van den Bekeron, 2012], a Canadian randomized controlled trial on the effects of physiotherapy on ankle sprain injuries [Brison, 2016], and expert opinion in a review article on hamstring injuries [Chu, 2016], on knee injuries [Robb, 2007; Strudwick, 2017], on ankle and foot injuries [Strudwick 2017; Chen, 2019; Nickless, 2019], and hand and wrist injuries [Strudwick, 2018].

Arranging referral to an emergency department
  • The recommendations on when further emergency department assessment is needed is largely pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice. It is also supported by the expert opinion of previous external reviewers of this CKS topic.
Advising on the use of analgesia
  • The evidence for analgesia options is largely based on limited data from systematic reviews.
    • A Dutch consensus statement on ankle sprains notes [Vuurberg, 2018]:
      • Paracetamol seems to be equally effective as NSAIDs based on three randomized controlled trials (RCTs; n = 450), specifically for pain based on one RCT (n = 86), for swelling based on two RCTs (n = 186), and range of movement based on one RCT (n = 100).
      • Pooling the results of studies, it showed the use of oral or topical NSAIDs results in less pain in the short-term (less than 14 days) without significantly increasing the risk of adverse events, compared with placebo (26 RCTs, n = 4225). It noted, however, that NSAIDs may suppress or delay the natural healing process.
      • It found that opioid analgesics (such as codeine) are equally effective for pain relief, but lead to significantly more adverse effects (based on two RCTs, n = 869).
      • The approach of favouring paracetamol first-line is supported by expert opinion in review articles that note that paracetamol is probably the most cost-effective and potentially least harmful choice of analgesia for soft tissue knee injuries [Robb, 2007], and paracetamol is an equally effective alternative to NSAIDs for the pain management of ankle injuries [Chen, 2019]. 
    • A Cochrane systematic review of 16 low- or very-low quality RCTs (n = 2144) of oral NSAIDs compared with other oral analgesia found [Jones, 2015]:
      • Nine studies (n = 991) compared NSAIDs with paracetamol. While tending to favour paracetamol, there was a lack of clinically important differences between the two groups in outcomes of pain, swelling, and return to function, at less than 24 hours up to 7 days and over.
      • Four studies (n = 958) compared NSAIDs with opioids. There was low-quality evidence for a lack of clinically important differences between the two groups regarding pain at less than 24 hours, at days 4–6, and at day 7. Evidence from single studies showed a similar lack of difference between the two groups for swelling at days 3 and 10. There was low-quality evidence supporting the use of NSAIDs for return to function at day 7 or over. Overall, it found low- or very low-quality evidence of improved function and fewer adverse events with NSAIDs compared with opioid-containing analgesics.
      • It concluded there is generally low- or very low-quality but consistent evidence of no clinically important difference in efficacy between NSAIDs and other oral analgesics for pain relief.
      • The included studies were of variable methodological quality and were at variable risk of bias.
    • A Cochrane systematic review of 61 studies of the efficacy and safety of topical NSAIDs found [Derry, 2015]:
      • Moderate- or high-quality evidence that formulations of topical diclofenac, ibuprofen, ketoprofen, piroxicam, and indomethacin provided significantly more study participants with at least 50% pain intensity reduction than topical placebo preparations.
      • Topical NSAIDs provided good levels of pain relief in acute conditions such as sprains, strains and overuse injuries, probably similar to that provided by oral NSAIDs. Gel formulations of diclofenac, ibuprofen, and ketoprofen provided the best results.
      • There were insufficient data to compare reliably individual topical NSAIDs with each other or the same oral NSAID.
      • There was high-quality evidence of very few systemic adverse events, and low-quality data of very few withdrawals due to adverse events.
    • A meta-analysis of 28 RCTs of the effectiveness and safety of topical and oral NSAIDs for acute ankle sprain found limited evidence for the short-term use of NSAIDs [van den Bekeron, 2015]:
      • It reported favourable results for oral NSAIDs when compared with placebo regarding pain on weight-bearing in the short-term, pain at rest in the short-term, and swelling in the short- and medium-term.
      • Similarly, it reported favourable results for topical NSAIDs when compared with placebo for pain at rest in the short-term, persistent pain in the medium-term, pain on weight-bearing in the short- and medium-term, and for swelling in the short- and medium-term.
      • No trials were included comparing oral with topical NSAIDs.
Advising on initial 'PRICE' (protection, rest, ice, compression, and elevation) self-management strategies
  • CKS found insufficient evidence to determine the relative effectiveness of PRICE measures for acute sprains and strains.
    • The recommendation on protection of the joint or muscle is pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be good medical practice. It is also supported by the expert opinion of previous external reviewers of this CKS topic.
    • A systematic review of 11 RCTs (n = 868 adults) of the effectiveness of rest, ice, compression, and/or elevation started within 72 hours of an acute ankle sprain found [van den Bekeron, 2012]:
      • Insufficient evidence on the relative effectiveness of 'RICE' therapy.
      • No randomized trials were available on the effectiveness of elevation measures.
      • Most of the included studies were of low quality.
      • Treatment decisions should be made on an individual basis, whilst considering the relative risks and benefits of each option.
    • An overview of 46 systematic reviews on the treatment and prevention of acute and recurrent ankle sprain found [Doherty, 2017]:
      • There was a lack of good-quality evidence on the use of 'RICE' protocols.
      • Applying ice and compression or the use of elevation is generally used concurrently with an exercise therapy intervention. It is unknown if a RICE protocol improves the effect of exercise, but it noted the strong empirical evidence base for ice treatment, particularly for the outcome of pain.
    • A Dutch consensus statement notes that 'RICE' is a conservative treatment method that has not been rigorously investigated, with limited evidence of efficacy for reducing injury-associated symptoms following acute lateral ankle sprain. It highlights [Vuurberg, 2018]:
      • Limited evidence from 33 RCTs (n = 2337) that showed the efficacy of ice therapy for reducing ankle sprain symptoms is unclear.
      • Limited evidence from one small RCT (n = 30) that in combination with exercise therapy, ice therapy has a greater effect on reducing swelling compared with heat application.
      • The combination of ice with exercise therapy results in significant improvements in ankle function in the short-term, allowing people to weight-bear more comfortably compared with 'standard functional treatment' (based on one RCT, n = 101), however, it states the individual aspects of RICE are not effective (and found no evidence for the individual effects of rest and elevation after lateral ankle sprain injury).
      • The use of RICE plus 'multimodal' physiotherapy compared with RICE alone provides no additional benefits. Both treatments provided pain reduction, increased function, and reduced ankle swelling (based on one small RCT, n = 28).
      • Overall, it found no evidence that RICE alone, or ice therapy, or compression therapy alone has any positive influence on pain, swelling, or ankle function. It noted a short time of immobilization may help to reduce pain and swelling in cases of lateral ligament injury.
    • A systematic review of the management of ankle sprains found that [Seah, 2011]:
      • For mild-to-moderate injuries, functional treatment options (such as elastic bandaging, soft casting, taping, or orthoses with associated coordination training) were statistically better than immobilization, for multiple outcome measures.
      • For severe ankle sprains, a short period of immobilization (in a below-knee cast or pneumatic brace) resulted in a quicker recovery than tubular compression bandage alone.
    • Expert opinion in various review articles has noted the poor evidence base for the use of standard practice 'RICE' protocols.
      • An article on acute knee injuries notes there is no evidence that RICE is effective for acute musculoskeletal injuries, however, it is widely accepted as standard management [Robb, 2007].
      • An article on acute ankle sprains notes the evidence supporting the RICE approach is limited, however, it states it is a reasonable intervention in the acute phase of ankle sprain for short-term symptomatic pain control to facilitate early mobilization [Chen, 2019].
      • An additional article on ankle and foot injuries in emergency departments states all levels of severity of ankle sprain can be effectively treated with RICE and a short period of non-weight bearing, with a view to increase weight-bearing depending on severity and stability. It noted, however, there was little consensus on the best approach in terms of immobilization type and duration [Strudwick 2017].
      • An article on acute hamstring strain injuries notes initial management should include the RICE protocol [Chu, 2016].
Advising on sources of information and support
  • The recommendations on advising on the safe return to usual activities and sport is extrapolated from the International Ankle Consortium consensus statement [Delahunt, 2018], a systematic review on conservative management of ankle sprains [van den Bekeron, 2012], US clinical practice guidelines on knee ligament sprain [Logerstedt, 2017], and expert opinion in a review article on ankle sprains [Chen, 2019].
    • High re-injury rates or chronic ankle instability might be due to inadequate rehabilitation and/or premature return to sport [Delahunt, 2018].
    • A systematic review of low-quality studies suggests that early mobilization leads to more rapid recovery than rest or immobilization [van den Bekeron, 2012]. Similarly, the US clinical practice guidelines recommend interventions of early mobilization and weight-bearing to improve outcomes following knee sprains [Logerstedt, 2017].
    • Athletes may return to play when there is a full, painless range of motion and strength is restored [Chen, 2019].
Arranging medical review
  • The recommendation to consider re-assessing a sprain or strain injury after a few days is largely extrapolated from evidence in systematic reviews.
    • A Dutch consensus statement on ankle sprains notes the severity of ligament damage can be assessed most reliably by delayed physical examination 4–5 days following trauma [Vuurberg, 2018].
      • The sensitivity (84%) and specificity (96%) of physical examination using the anterior drawer test are optimized if clinical assessment is delayed for between 4–5 days post-injury.
    • This approach is supported by a systematic review that recommends reassessment of acute ankle sprains after 4–5 days, as physical examination within 48 hours of trauma can be misleading or challenging owing to the diffuse character of pain, swelling that may be due to oedema or haematoma formation, and the unreliability of special ligament tests owing to pain and swelling [van den Bekeron, 2012].
    • A review of ankle sprain guidelines notes consistent evidence to support a clinical reassessment 4–5 days post-injury to better assess the severity of injury [Strudwick 2017].
    • A systematic review of the Ottowa ankle rules clinical decision tool for ruling out ankle fracture recommends repeating a clinical examination after a few days to determine the severity of an ankle sprain, to allow identification of a missed fracture [Jonckheer, 2015].
    • Similarly, expert opinion in a review article notes that assessment for ligament tears is more accurate when acute pain and swelling have subsided at about 10 days [Robb, 2007].
  • The recommendation to consider an alternative diagnosis if a person's symptoms are not resolving as expected is extrapolated from the US clinical practice guidelines on knee ligament sprain [Logerstedt, 2017]. It is also pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
Arranging referral to physiotherapy
  • The recommendation on when to arrange referral to physiotherapy is based on mixed evidence from systematic reviews and smaller studies.
    • A Canadian RCT (n = 503) on the effect of early supervised physiotherapy on recovery from grade I or II acute ankle sprain found no evidence to support the addition of supervised physiotherapy to usual care (written instructions regarding PRICE measures and graduated weight-bearing activities) when clinical outcome and recovery was assessed at 6 months [Brison, 2016].
    • A review of knee injury guidelines found referral for physiotherapy may be needed for further clinical assessment or rehabilitation following ligamentous, meniscal, and soft tissue injuries. It noted that bracing and biomechanical interventions may also be appropriate [Strudwick, 2017]. A further guideline review notes the severity and stability of ankle and foot injuries should guide immobilization, weight-bearing status, and specialist and/or physiotherapy referral decisions [Strudwick 2017].
    • A meta-analysis of 46 systematic reviews on the treatment and prevention of acute and recurrent ankle sprain found [Doherty, 2017]:
      • For the combined outcomes of pain, swelling, and function after an acute sprain, there was strong evidence for early mobilization, with moderate evidence supporting exercise and manual therapy techniques.
      • Bracing (including taping, external support, and orthoses) is recommended during exercise for 6–12 months after injury to improve stability and prevent recurrence. It also found strong evidence that exercise therapy can help prevent recurrence.
    • A consensus statement on the management of ankle sprains recommends the use of functional support in combination with a supervised exercise programme to stimulate the recovery of functional joint stability [Vuurberg, 2018].
      • The use of functional support (ankle brace or tape) for 4–6 weeks is preferred over immobilization for the management of acute lateral ankle sprain, which allows the person to load the damaged tissues in a protected manner, and is more effective than support with compression bandage or a tubigrip.
      • It found conflicting evidence that supervised exercise therapy may lead to improvements in ankle strength and proprioception, and faster return to work and sport, compared with performing the exercise programme without supervision or guidance.
      • There was no effect on pain, oedema, function, and return to play for the use of ultrasound, and evidence on acupuncture was inconclusive due to large heterogeneity between studies.
    • The International Ankle Consortium consensus statement on lateral ankle sprains notes that conservative management using a variety of physiotherapy techniques can be used for people with chronic ankle instability, with improvements in self-reported outcomes and functional measurements [Gribble, 2016].
    • US clinical practice guidelines on knee ligament sprains recommends the option of functional knee bracing, together with early to late interventions of therapeutic knee, ankle/foot, hip, and trunk exercises and neuromuscular re-education to improve outcomes [Logerstedt, 2017].
    • Expert opinion in a review article on acute hamstring strain injuries recommends the use of exercises and neuromuscular training in order to allow a return to usual activities and sports [Chu, 2016].
Arranging referral to orthopaedics
  • The recommendations on when to arrange referral to orthopaedics are based on mixed evidence from systematic reviews and smaller studies. They are also pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice, as persistent or worsening symptoms may suggest more severe injury or an alternative diagnosis.
    • An overview of 46 systematic reviews on the treatment and prevention of acute and recurrent ankle sprain found [Doherty, 2017]:
      • A trial of conservative treatment should always be attempted before surgical intervention, and the decision to offer surgery should be considered only in people with persistent symptoms on an individual basis.
    • A consensus statement on the management of ankle sprains states [Vuurberg, 2018]:
      • Surgery should be reserved for cases that do not respond to thorough and comprehensive exercise-based physiotherapy treatment, particularly for people who have chronic instability after a lateral ankle sprain.
      • For suspected high-grade ligament injuries, osteochondral defects, or occult fractures, an MRI may be arranged owing to its high sensitivity and specificity to identify these injuries, particularly if there are persistent symptoms.
      • Despite good clinical outcomes of surgery after both chronic injuries and an acute complete lateral ligament rupture, functional treatment is still preferred. It notes, however, that in professional athletes, surgical treatment may be offered to ensure quicker return to play.
    • MRI remains the gold standard for imaging the ligamentous and intra-articular structures of the knee and ankle [Robb, 2007; Logerstedt, 2017; Strudwick 2017; Chen, 2019].
      • US clinical practice guidelines highlight the role of MRI in identifying knee meniscal or cruciate ligament lesions [Logerstedt, 2017].
      • Expert opinion in review articles notes the high incidence of ankle sprains, false-positive findings, limited availability, and high cost limit the use of MRI in the routine management of acute ankle sprains. As a result, MRI should be reserved for cases of persistent symptoms in severe sprains and chronic ankle instability to rule out osteochondral defects, missed syndesmotic (multiple ligament complex) injuries, or bony injuries not identified on X-ray [Strudwick 2017; Chen, 2019].

subChapters.htmlHeader: What should I advise on preventing re-injury?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
If a person has sustained a sprain or strain following initial management in primary care:

  • Ensure that referral to physiotherapy to consider measures such as external support (bracing or taping) has been arranged, if needed.
  • Advise on self-care strategies when doing exercise or sport.
    • Warm up before exercising (by doing an aerobic activity at an easy pace to gently increase the heart rate and get the body and muscles ready for more intense activity). Cool down after exercising (by gradually decreasing the exercise intensity level until breathing and heart rate have returned to normal, then doing gentle stretches whilst the muscles are still warm).
    • Use proper equipment.
    • Wear appropriate shoes (and replace shoes as they wear out) and wear comfortable, loose-fitting clothes that allow free movement.
    • Develop a balanced fitness programme that incorporates cardiovascular exercise, strength training, and flexibility. Add new activities and exercises cautiously.
    • Avoid exercising or playing sport when tired or in pain.
    • Schedule regular days off from exercise.
  • Manage any factors that increase the risk of re-injury or falls, where possible.
    • See the CKS topics on Falls - risk assessment, Alcohol - problem drinking, and Obesity for more information.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on injury prevention are largely based on two Cochrane systematic reviews Interventions for preventing hamstring injuries [Goldman, 2010] and Interventions for preventing lower limb soft-tissue running injuries [Yeung, 2011], a meta-analysis of the treatment and prevention of acute and recurrent ankle sprain [Doherty, 2017], a Dutch consensus statement on the diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of ankle sprains [Vuurberg, 2018], US clinical practice guidelines on exercise-based knee injury prevention programmes [Arundale, 2018], a systematic review of strength training interventions [Lauersen, 2018], a systematic review of bracing and balance training on ankle sprain injuries [Bellows, 2018], and a meta-analysis of exercise training for prevention of hamstring injuries in athletes [Vatovec, 2019].

Advising on physiotherapy referral and self-care strategies
  • The recommendations on physiotherapy referral and self-care strategies when exercising are based on limited, conflicting evidence in the literature, and are also pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
    • A meta-analysis of 46 systematic reviews on the treatment and prevention of acute and recurrent ankle sprain found [Doherty, 2017]:
      • That measures such as external support with bracing or taping provided a similar re-injury risk reduction of 50%, and their beneficial effect could be improved with an appropriately designed exercise therapy programme.
        • Braces were recommended for all athletes with a previous history of ankle sprain, particularly when engaging in high-risk activities such as indoor/court and field sports.
      • Moderate-quality evidence for exercise intervention/neuromuscular training, in preventing recurrence of an ankle sprain injury.
    • A consensus statement notes that postural balance control and ligament laxity after acute lateral ankle sprain can be improved with physiotherapy, which may also prevent progression to chronic ankle instability [Vuurberg, 2018].
      • It found that exercise therapy programmes can prevent recurrent strains (based on 10 randomized controlled trials [RCTs], n = 1284) and reduce the risk of functional ankle instability (based on 3 RCTs, n = 174). Furthermore, they are associated with a quicker time to recovery. Exercise therapy such as coordination and balance training mainly seem to be effective for recurrent ankle sprains up to 12 months after the initial sprain.
      • The use of brace or tape functional support reduces the risk of both first-time and recurrent lateral ankle sprains, but is particularly effective in preventing recurrent sprains, especially in those who participate in sports.
      • It found no evidence for the role of footwear in the prevention of ankle sprains.
    • A systematic review of eight moderate-quality studies of bracing and balance training on ankle sprain injuries in athletes with or without previous injury, found evidence to support the use of bracing and balance training to reduce the incidence and relative risk of ankle sprains [Bellows, 2018]:
      • Athletes who wore braces (n = 3581) had fewer ankle sprains and reduced their risk of sprains by 64% compared with controls (no intervention).
      • Athletes performing balance training (n = 3577) had fewer ankle sprains and reduced their risk by 46% compared with controls.
      • There was insufficient evidence to recommend whether bracing, balance training, or both combined provide the most protective effect.
    • A meta-analysis of 17 RCTs and prospective cohort studies of exercise training for prevention of hamstring injuries in athletes found [Vatovec, 2019]:
      • Exercise interventions decreased hamstring injury risk (relative risk = 0.49). The weekly frequency of exercises and progression of exercise volume/intensity did not influence outcomes. The authors noted various limitations including the fact re-injury rates were not assessed, and variations in definition of injury between studies. It concluded that all eccentric exercise, balance training, and muscle stretching are effective strategies to reduce hamstring injury rates. 
    • A Cochrane systematic review of seven RCTs (n = 1919 predominantly young adults participating in regular sporting activities) found [Goldman, 2010]:
      • Four trials (n = 287) examining interventions directly targeted at preventing hamstring injuries. Three of these trials, which tested hamstring strengthening protocols, had contradictory findings, with one small trial showing benefit. Two other trials found no benefit, and one unpublished and underpowered trial provided some evidence that manual therapy may prevent lower limb muscle strain, although the finding for hamstring injury did not reach statistical significance.
      • There is insufficient evidence from RCTs to draw conclusions on the effectiveness of interventions used to prevent hamstring injuries, such as strength training, warm up, cool down, and stretching.
    • A Cochrane systematic review of 25 randomized or quasi-randomized trials (n = 30,252) on interventions to prevent lower limb soft tissue running injuries, such as exercises, modification of training schedules, use of orthoses, and footwear and socks, found [Yeung, 2011]:
      • No evidence from six trials that stretching reduces injuries.
      • No evidence from one trial to support a training regimen of conditioning exercises to improve strength, flexibility, and coordination.
      • No evidence from one trial that a longer, more gradual increase in training reduces injuries in novice runners.
      • Limited evidence from two trials that injuries were less frequent when running duration or frequency were reduced.
      • No evidence from two trials that wearing running shoes based on foot shape, rather than standard running shoes, significantly reduced the rate of running injuries.
    • US clinical practice guidelines on knee injury recommend [Arundale, 2018]:
      • The use of exercise-based knee injury prevention programmes in athletes for the prevention of knee and anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injuries. It found no evidence of harm from such programmes.
    • A systematic review and meta-analysis of six RCTs on strength training exercises as primary prevention of sports injuries (n = 7738 with 177 acute or overuse injuries) found [Lauersen, 2018]:
      • A 10% increase in strength training volume reduced the risk of injury by more than 4%, despite differences in study populations and interventions. Increasing strength training volume and intensity were associated with sports injury risk reduction.
      • Strength training programmes reduced the risk of sports injury by more than 50%.
Managing risk factors for re-injury and falls
  • The recommendations on managing risk factors are based on a Dutch consensus statement on prevention of ankle sprains [Vuurberg, 2018] and are pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be sensible clinical practice.
